output.conclusion: This course provides a solid foundation in inorganic chemistry, equipping students with the knowledge and skills necessary for further study in related fields.
output.introduction: Welcome to Intermediate Inorganic Chemistry! This course builds upon your existing knowledge of chemistry to explore the fascinating world of inorganic compounds, their structure, bonding, and reactivity.

chapters.description: Review of atomic structure, electronic configuration, and periodic trends relevant to inorganic chemistry. Focus on ionization energy, electronegativity, and atomic/ionic radii.
Detailed analysis of periodic trends including electronegativity, ionization energy, electron affinity, and their influence on chemical properties of elements.
Formation of ionic compounds, lattice energy, Born-Haber cycle. Introduction to common crystal structures (NaCl, CsCl, ZnS) and their properties.

chapters.chapterTitle: Covalent Bonding and Molecular Orbital Theory
chapters.description: Review of covalent bonding, Lewis structures, VSEPR theory. Introduction to molecular orbital theory for diatomic molecules (homonuclear and heteronuclear).
Definition of coordination complexes, ligands, and metal ions. Nomenclature and isomerism in coordination compounds.
Valence bond theory and crystal field theory applied to coordination complexes. Factors affecting crystal field splitting.

chapters.chapterTitle: Acids and Bases in Inorganic Chemistry
chapters.description: Review of Arrhenius, Bronsted-Lowry, and Lewis acid-base theories. Hard and Soft Acids and Bases (HSAB) principle.
Understanding the role of solvents in inorganic reactions. Protic and aprotic solvents. Liquid ammonia as a solvent.
Definition and scope of organometallic chemistry. 18-electron rule and its applications.
Overview of common ligands such as CO, phosphines, and cyclopentadienyl. Bonding modes and their influence on reactivity.
